revisions.rev:
[[Image:Acc challengelogo.png|thumb|300px|right|ACC - Big Ten Challenge logo]] Beginning in 1999, the '''ACC â Big Ten Challenge''' (or '''Big Ten â ACC Challenge''' as it is called in alternating years) is an in-season [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] college [[basketball]] series, matching up teams from the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]] and the [[Big Ten Conference]]. [[ESPN]] was a key part of the creation of the challenge, and holds the broadcast rights to all the games. The ACC has won 10 out of the 13 challenges; the Big Ten's first win was in 2009, ending the ten-year ACC stranglehold and have won the challenge the past 3 years. Seven of the challenges, including 2 of the Big Ten's 3 victories, have been won by a single game. The Big Ten - ACC Challenge occurs early in the season, typically around late November/early December. Each game is hosted by one of the participating schools, with teams typically alternating home and away status in each successive year. Nine games were played for each of the first 6 challenges, leaving two teams from the 11-team Big Ten Conference without an opponent. With the expansion of the ACC to 12 teams with the addition of [[Boston College]], [[University of Miami|Miami]] and [[Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University|Virginia Tech]], the field was expanded to 11 games in 2006, meaning that one ACC team would not play. With [[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] joining the Big Ten in 2011, the challenge is now expanded to 12 games and every member from both conferences will participate. Because the challenge has been expanded to 12 games, there is now the possibility that the challenge will end in a tie. In the event of a tie, the previous year's winner will retain the Commissioner's Cup.http://www.freep.com/article/20111129/SPORTS06/111290396/U-M-confident-can-succeed-road-ACC-Big-Ten-Challenge [[ESPN]], the [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]] and the [[Atlantic Coast Conference|ACC]] announced in early 2005 that they were extending the challenge for an additional six years.[http://bigten.collegesports.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/022205aaa.html] Despite the [[Atlantic Coast Conference|ACC]]'s advantage in the series, both conferences have had significant success on the national stage. Since the inception of the Challenge, a total of 9 teams from each of these conferences have gone on to play in the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|Final Four]], with 2000 national champion [[Michigan State University|Michigan State]], 2001 and 2010 national champion [[Duke University|Duke]], 2002 national champion [[University of Maryland, College Park|Maryland]], and 2005 and 2009 national champion [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|North Carolina]] among them. In the year 2007, the [[ACC â Big Ten Women's Challenge]] was founded. ==Team records== === Atlantic Coast Conference (10â3) === {| class="wikitable sortable" !style="background:#efefef; align="center" width="250pt" |Institution !style="background:#efefef;
